awd_titl_txt: CAREER:Toward robust, scalable, and non-intermittent solar power: Silicon-based multijunction devices with integrated photocatalysis
awd_abstract_narration:
Research Objectives and Approaches:
The research objective is to create a silicon-based multijunction solar cell device with integrated photoelectrochemical capability, resulting in a high-efficiency, robust, and easily manufacturable device capable of converting sunlight into storable chemical energy. A systematic approach toward device optimization will be implemented, combining simulation, device fabrication, and hierarchical nanoscale characterization.

Intellectual Merit:
This project seeks to leverage the inherent advantages of silicon for photovoltaic applications (reliability, scalability, performance, manufacturability, over 60 years of accumulated R&D) while overcoming its inherent disadvantages (high cost, low efficiency, intermittency). Collaborations between the PI?s PV-focused group and catalysis experts will ensure rapid interdisciplinary progress. 

Scientific challenges will be addressed in a systematic fashion: (1) High-performance sub-devices (individual solar cells) will be created; (2) Sub-devices will be integrated into a single high-performance silicon-based multijunction cell; (3) Aforementioned devices will be integrated with catalyst materials. The envisioned result is a silicon-based multijunction device capable of direct solar-to-fuels conversion.

Broader Impacts:
This project addresses five critical needs enabling utility-scale implementation of solar energy conversion: low cost, high efficiency, non-intermittency (dispatchability), scalability, and domestic manufacturability. Close interaction with local companies will ensure expedient technology transfer and student internship opportunities. Outreach efforts will improve solar energy education via augmenting a university course, engaging the general public at local museums and interactive websites, and educating future thought leaders. Underrepresented minorities will be engaged in solar energy research and engineering through an active mentorship program.

por.por_cntn:
Key outcomes from this research grant include:

 

We showed how to make efficient devices that convert sunlight into fuel. Solar cells produce energy when the sun is shining. That energy often needs to be stored for later use, for example, at night. We made a significant advance in demonstrating that solar energy can be stored efficiently for later use. We combined a solar cell device (that converts sunlight to electricity) with a photocatalytic device (that converts electricity to fuel), and demonstrated a working 10% solar-to-fuel conversion efficiency. Prior conversion efficiencies for such solar-to-fuel devices were well below 1%. Our device uses all Earth-abundant elements (no rare metals), which means it can in principle be scaled to satisfy the Earth’s power needs. The key underlying physics was elucidated and embodied in an equivalent-circuit model. The two key research papers that showed our concept were published in the Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences, and now have 120 citations combined. This led to a flurry of follow-up work in the field of solar-to-fuel research using buried-junction photovoltaic devices. We collaborated with catalyst expert Daniel Nocera (Harvard) on this work; his start-up company, SunCatalytix, was successfully acquired.

 

To further reduce the cost of solar cells, we developed foundational knowledge that increases the conversion efficiency of low-cost, scalable, thin-film solar cells (alternatives to wafer-based crystalline silicon). One of the main energy losses for thin-film solar cells occurs at the interface between the sunlight absorbing layer (called “absorber”) and the layer that extracts charge from the device (called “charge-extraction layer”). We showed how to minimize losses at this interface, which improved device performance by 4x in one thin-film material called cuprous oxide. The key was to deposit, using atomic-layer deposition, a thin interfacial layer between the absorber and the charge-extraction layer, which would serve as a “buffer” between the two. Follow-up work demonstrated that this approach was broadly applicable to other thin-film solar cell material systems (leading to a recent record efficiency for a two-terminal perovskite-silicon tandem solar cell of 23.6%, which mimicked this approach by using a buffer layer of nickel oxide grown by atomic-layer deposition).

 

To improve the use and tracking of data in the lab, we developed the foundations of a lab-scale data analytics system. This will be useful once machine learning becomes widespread, and these data can be input into large databases that will help improve the rate of learning in materials science. This work is being continued in both my laboratory and in the research group of Prof. Rafael Jaramillo, who was a postdoc in my lab during the course of this CAREER grant.
